context.text: The proposed memory scheduler is based on concepts from network fair queuing (FQ) [1] [17] [20] [24].
Network FQ scheduling algorithms offer guaranteed service to simultaneous network flows over a shared network link [1] [16] [19] [23].
Network FQ scheduling algorithms use a virtual clock [1] [23] to determine the virtual arrival time \$a_{i}^{k}\$.
An important characteristic of a scheduling algorithm's fairness is the extent to which a flow receiving excess service in a given time period will be penalized in later time period(s) [1] [23].
Given the virtual start- and finish-times, there are a number of ways an FQ scheduling algorithm can prioritize packets; each with slightly different QoS and fairness properties [1].
For example, packets can be prioritized earliest virtual start-time first [23] or earliest virtual finish-time first [1] [19].

Prioritizing memory requests VFTF also satisfies this fairness policy because a thread whose oldest pending memory request has the earliest virtual finish-time has consumed less excess service (normalized to its share \$\phi_{i}\$) than any other backlogged thread [1].

The second solution is to calculate the virtual finish-times of memory requests just before they are scheduled to begin service [1], i.e., when a memory request becomes a thread's oldest first-ready request, and update the VTMS resource finish-time registers after the request has been issued to the memory system.

There are few literatures [17], [18] about the APS of CNNs with distributed delays.
The CNNs studied in [17] are described by (1), which can retrospect to [18] for \$i=1,\cdots,n\$, where \$n\$ denotes the total number of units in the CNNs.

This letter studies the existence, uniqueness, and stability of the APS of CNNs (1), and drops the restrictions \$\int_{0}^{\infty}k_{ij}(s)ds=1\$ and \$\int_{0}^{\infty}sk_{ij}(s)ds<+\infty\$, and extends and improves the criteria in [17] and [18].

Theorem 1 of [17] indicates that if there exists a positive diagonal matrix \${\rm diag}(\rho_{i})\$ such thatthen (1) has a unique APS under conditions H2), \$\int_{0}^{+\infty}k(s)ds=(1)_{n\times n}\$ and \$f(0)=g(0)=(0)_{n\times 1}\$.

Comparing (13) with (4), (9), and (12), we can see Theorem 2 is an improved form of Theorem 1 in [17], when its term \$\rho\bar{b}{\rm diag}(\mu_{j}\beta_{j})\$ is replaced by \$\rho(\bar{b}\otimes\mathhat{k}){\rm diag}(\beta_{j}\vert\mu_{j}\vert)\rho^{-1}\$.
Theorem 3 of [17] indicates (13) and ensures the global stability of the APS; here, we provide two methods to insure the stability obtained by completely different approach.

As for Example 2, since \$\int_{0}^{\infty}k_{ij}(s)ds>1\$, the criteria of [17] and [18] are not applicable, while our theorems give correct assertions which do completely accord with the numerical simulated results.
